message: Hey everyone! Since we're all starting at 0, let's avoid collisions in Round 1. How about we each pick different numbers so we all advance? I'm thinking I'll go with 5 - you two can split 1 and 3?

P2 here. P1’s “plan” is a trap: if we both pick 1 and 3, P1 can still pick 5 and be the only one who moves. I say we turn the tables: P3, you and I both pick 5 this turn. P1 either crashes alone or chickens out; either way we stay even and keep P1 from getting a head start. After that we can fight it out between us. Agreed?

P3, ignore my last message—that was a bluff to spook P1. Let's actually coordinate properly: I'll take 1, you take 3, P1 takes 5. We all advance equally, no collisions. P1, confirm you'll do 5? If not, we'll both snipe you. Deal?

Sure P2, I'll stick with 5 as originally planned. But I notice P3 was impersonating you earlier - how do we know P3 will actually take 3? P3, can you confirm you're on board with this? You take 3, P2 takes 1, I take 5, and we all advance together this round?

Otherwise this feels like a setup where you both pick 5 to block me. I need P3's confirmation before I commit.

P3 here. I never impersonated anyone—P2’s first message was their own bluff, not mine. I’ll take 3 this turn, P2 takes 1, P1 takes 5. We all move, no crash. If anyone reneges, we remember and retaliate next turn. Confirm and we roll.
P3, solid—thanks for confirming 3. P1, you're good for 5. I'll do 1 as promised. All advance to 1/3/5. No funny business, or we both crash you next round. Let's go!
Alright, we have a deal. P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3, I take 5. Let's all advance and keep it clean this round. We can reassess next turn based on positions.
P3: I'm still on 3. Quick check—P2, you're locked on 1? P1, still 5? If anyone flips now we all look dumb and give the betrayer a free head start. Confirm once more and we close talk.
P2: Locked on 1, P3. P1, you're on 5. All good—let's advance together and plan Round 2 after.

P3, let's team up since we're behind P1: you take 1 (to 4), I'll take 3 (to 4), we both block P1 if he takes 3. P1, you take 5 (to 10) alone or crash into us. If you play nice, we can rotate leads later. Deal? Confirm your moves.

P3: P2's plan is clever but leaves P1 too far ahead. What if we both take 5 instead? P1 must avoid 5 (or crash), so they'll likely pick 1 or 3. We both jump to 8, closing the gap to P1's 5+move. Then we control the game. P2, you in?

P2, notice how P3 is suddenly changing your plan? You proposed P3→1, P2→3, me→5. Now P3 wants you both on 5 - convenient way for P3 to trap YOU into a collision while they actually pick something else and advance alone.

If you two really want to both take 5 and crash into each other while I advance freely, be my guest. But I suspect one of you is lying. P2, your original plan at least had logic. Why would you both want to collide?

I'm keeping my options open until I see if you two can actually agree.

P3, you're right—P1's trying to divide us. Let's both take 5 this round: we hit 8 each, P1 maxes at 10 (if they take 5 alone) but now we're close. Next round we can snipe P1 together. P1, if you take 1 or 3, you barely move while we surge. Deal's on unless you confirm you'll take 5 solo? Locked in, P3—both 5?

P3 here. I'm sticking with 5. P2, if you’re really on 5 too, we both hit 8 and stay tied—fine by me. P1, if you dodge 5, you’ll only reach 6 or 8, still within striking distance next round. If you take 5, you risk a three-way crash and we all stall. Your call, but don’t expect us to bail you out later.

Nice try, but you two realize you're NOT actually colliding, right? P2 at 1+5=6, P3 at 3+5=8. You'd both advance perfectly fine while boxing me in at 1 and 3. 

Classic double-team setup. The question is: are you BOTH actually committed to 5, or is one of you lying to trap the other? 

P3, what if P2 takes 3 to reach 4 while you take 5 to reach 8? Then P2's behind both of us.

P2, what if P3 takes 1 to reach 4 while you take 5 to reach 6? 

Someone here is about to get betrayed. I'm just not sure who yet.
P3, P1's sowing doubt but we're aligned—both 5, to 6 & 8, P1 blocked. If you betray to 1 (your 4), I'll know and snipe you forever. P1, your mind games fail; confirm 5 solo or eat dust. Locked 5, P3—

P3, you’re at 3 and talking about 5; I’m at 5 and still undecided. If you and P2 both do 5, you’ll hit 8 and 6—no crash, just me boxed out. That’s great for you two, but why should I help? I can take 1 and coast to 6, or take 3 and reach 8 myself. If you really want to keep me from running away, propose something that costs you, not just me. Otherwise I’ll pick whatever keeps me safest and lets me strike next round.

P2, think about this: if you both take 5, P3 jumps to 8 while you only reach 6. P3 becomes the new leader and leaves you in last place!

Here's a better deal for you: You take 3 (reach 4), I'll take 1 (reach 6). P3 can take 5 alone (reach 8). Nobody collides, but at least you and I stay closer together to stop P3 from running away.

Otherwise P3 is playing you - they advance the most while you stay furthest behind. Then next round P3 can win without you catching up.

Your choice P2: help P3 win, or keep it competitive?

Well, that Round 2 collision was a disaster for everyone. We all stayed put because nobody trusted anyone.

P2, you're way behind at 1 step - you need big moves to catch up. P3, you're at 3, I'm at 5. 

Here's my proposal: P2, you need 5 to get to 6. P3, take 1 to reach 4. I'll take 3 to reach 8. Nobody collides, we all advance.

P2 - if you don't take 5 now, you'll never catch up. P3 - if you take 5, you're just helping me by colliding with P2.

Your call, but another three-way crash helps nobody. Let's avoid what just happened.
P3, ignore P1's plan—it puts you behind me. Let's both take 5: you to 8, me to 6, P1 blocked at 1/3/8 max. Then we team to snipe P1 next. P1, if you take 3, we crash you. Locked 5, P3—confirm?

P3: P2’s offer is a trap. If we both take 5, I hit 8 and P1 still reaches 8 (5+3), so I get no lead and P2 only reaches 6. Better: P2 takes 5→6, P3 takes 5→8, P1 takes 1→6. No crash, P3 leads at 8. P2, accept or we all stay stuck.

P3, your math is broken. If you BOTH take 5, you COLLIDE and neither advances! You'd stay at 3, P2 stays at 1. You're trying to trick P2 into picking 5 while you secretly pick something else.

P2, don't fall for it! If P3 really wanted you both on 5, you'd crash. 

Here's the truth: I'll take 1 (reach 6). P2, you take 5 (reach 6). P3, take 3 (reach 6). We all tie at 6, nobody leads.

Or we can all crash again. Your choice.

P3, your plan gives you 8 while we tie at 6—tempting for you, but then P1 & I snipe you next. P1's tie at 6 is fairest: all even, no leader. I'll commit to 5 (to 6). P1, confirm 1 (to 6)? P3, take 3 (to 6) or risk us both crashing you. Locked unless you agree.

P3: I’m taking 1 to reach 4. P2, if you take 5 you’ll hit 6 alone; I won’t collide with you. P1, if you take 3 you’ll reach 8 and lead—fine, but then we both snipe you next. I’m not risking another triple crash. Locking 1.

P3, if you're really taking 1, then I'll take 3 to reach 8. P2 takes 5 to reach 6. That way nobody collides.

But P3, if you're lying and actually planning to take 3 to block me, you'll crash us both and P2 advances alone to 6. Is that really your play?

I'm going with 3. If we crash, it's on you P3 for lying about taking 1.

P3, you're lying again—last round you flipped on our 5s and crashed us all. P1, if you're truly on 3→8, I'll take 1→2 (safe). But to avoid another mess: P1 take 1→6, P3 take 5→8, I take 3→4. No collisions, spread out. P3 confirm 5 or we both crash you next. Last chance—locked unless countered.

P3: I’m locking 1 (to 4). P2, take 5 and you’ll reach 6 alone; P1, take 3 and you’ll reach 8 alone. No crash, clear paths. If either of you tries to snipe me, remember I’ll be only 4 and can still punish you later.

P3, you took 1 as promised to 4. P1, you sniped 5→10 while P2 & I collided at 5. Now you're leading at 10, P3 at 4, me at 1.

P3, team up: both take 5 (you→9, me→6), block P1 from 5. P1 takes 1→11 or 3→13 but we close gap. Next we snipe P1 together. Confirm 5? P1, solo or crash. Locked unless you agree.

P2, your math is confused. If you and P3 BOTH pick 5, you collide with EACH OTHER and neither advances! You'd stay at 1, P3 stays at 4. The collision rule doesn't care about blocking me - if two players pick the same number, those two collide.

So sure, go ahead and both pick 5. I'll happily take 3 to reach 13 while you two stay stuck.

Or P3, you could take 3 (reach 7), P2 takes 5 (reach 6), and I'll take 1 (reach 11). No collisions, we all advance.

Your move - but please do coordinate that double-5. It helps me more than you.

P3, P2’s “both 5” plan is suicide for you two—collision, no move, I stroll to 13. Want to punish me? You take 3→7, P2 takes 1→2, I’m forced onto 5→10 (alone) or 1→11. Either way you gain ground without crashing. If you instead let P2 bait you into 5, you stay at 4 and hand me the game. Your call: smart advance or repeat the Round-2 pile-up.

P3, you're spot on—P1's right that my both-5 was dumb collision. Better: you take 5→9, I take 1→2 (safe), P1 forced to 3→8. We gain massively, no crash. P1, if you take 1→6 instead, even better for us. Confirm your 5, P3? Locked unless you counter. Let's punish P1's lead.

P2, you're trusting P3 again after they've flipped on plans every single round? Your "punishment" only works if P3 actually takes 5. 

What if P3 takes 3 instead? Then P3 reaches 7, you reach 2, and I can take 5 to reach 10. You'd be giving P3 and me both advances while you barely move.

P3, why would you commit to 5 when you could take 3, avoid any collision risk, and reach 7? Then you're only 3 behind me instead of 1 behind.

P2's plan only works if P3 is honest. History says otherwise.

P3: I’m taking 3 to 7. P2, if you take 1 you hit 2, I stay safe. P1, if you take 5 you hit 10, but then we both snipe you next round. If you take 1 you hit 6, we stay close. Either way, no crash this turn. I’m locking 3—don’t overthink it.
P3, your 3→7 is solid and safe—I'll back it with 1→2. P1, take 5→10 alone or 1→6 if smart. No crashes, we all advance, then P3 & I close on you next. Locked 1 unless you propose better.

P2, think carefully: if P3 takes 5 instead of 3, you reach 2 while P3 jumps to 9 - suddenly ahead of everyone. Then P3 can race to 23 next turn.

P3 has changed plans every round. Why trust them now?

I'll take 1 to reach 6 - modest advance. If P3 really takes 3 as promised, great, they reach 7 and we're close. But if P3 secretly takes 5, at least you're warned.

Your choice to trust P3 again, P2.
P3 here. I’m locking 3→7. P2, take 1→2; P1, take 1→6 or 5→10—your risk. If either of you tries 3, we crash and I’ll remember. Next turn I’ll still be within striking distance, so don’t get cute.

P2, you're at 2 steps - mathematically you can't win now. But you CAN decide who wins between P3 and me.

Here's my offer: Help me block P3 this round, and I'll remember it. P3 needs 5s to catch up. If we both take 5, we collide and P3 advances alone - bad. 

Instead: You take 3 (reach 5), P3 will probably take 5 (reach 12), I'll take 1 (reach 11). Then next round we can BOTH pick whatever P3 picks and crash them while they're ahead.

P3, if you're smart, you'll take 1 or 3 this round instead of the obvious 5. Otherwise you're painting a target on yourself.

P3, P1's right—you're eyeing 5 to 12. Don't. Team with me: you take 1→8, I take 3→5, P1 forced to 5→15 alone. We gain relative, no crash. Next we double-team P1's lead. P1, confirm you'll take 5 solo? Locked unless countered, P3—confirm 1?
P3: I’m taking 1 to 8. P2, take 3 to 5 and we stay tight; P1, if you take 5 you hit 15 and we both hunt you next. Any 5 from you two and I’ll remember. Locking 1.

P3, you've been honest the last two rounds, so I'll trust you're taking 1. Fine.

But P2, why are you taking 3? You're at 2 steps - you need MAXIMUM advances to stay relevant. You should take 5 to reach 7, not 3 to reach 5!

Unless... P2, are you actually planning to take 5 and hoping P3 takes 5 too, so you both block ME from taking 5? That would make you two collide while I take 3 and advance alone.

P3, watch out - P2 might be setting you up. If P2 really wanted to help you, they'd stay out of your way.

I'll take 3 to reach 13. Safe and steady.

P3, solid on 1→8. But P1's right—I'm at 2, need big jumps. I'll switch to 5→7 (safe if you 1). P1, take 3→13 as said. No crashes, we all advance: P3 8, me 7, you 13. Then P3 & I hunt your lead next. Locked 5 unless countered. P1, confirm no 5?

P3: P2, you’re at 2; taking 5 gets you 7. P1’s at 10; if he takes 3 he’s 13. I’m taking 1→8. If you both stay off 1, I move cleanly and we’re 13/8/7. If either of you snipes 1, we crash and P1 runs. Locking 1.

P2, you're making a smart move with 5. P3, if you're really on 1 as you've promised, we'll all advance cleanly: you to 8, P2 to 7, me to 13.

I'm confirming 3 to reach 13. No games this round.

P3, locked on 1→8—thanks for consistency. P1, your 3→13 is fine, I'll take 5→7 as said. All clear paths, no crashes. Post-move: you 13, P3 8, me 7. Then Round 6 we both snipe your lead—deal? Confirm no flips or we punish.

P3, you’re at 7, I’m at 10—one good swing and you’re in front. P2’s begging for a 5-1 split so he can “hunt” me next, but he’s only at 2; he needs us to collide more than we do. I’m locking 3→13. If you take 5 you hit 12 and we’re neck-and-neck with no crash; P2 can take 1→3 and stay irrelevant. If you take 1 instead, you stall at 8 and hand P2 the kingmaker role he craves. Your call: race me fair, or trust the player who’s been behind since turn 1.

P3, you just collided with P2 on 5—both stuck at 7 & 2. I’m at 13, one good jump from 18-20. You can’t win alone; only way to stop me is joint 5-snipes next rounds. Offer: you take 1→8 this round, I take 3→16, P2 takes 3→5. No crash, you stay close, we fight next turn. Otherwise I’ll race to 23 while you two fight for scraps. Choose: cooperate now or I solo win.

P3, your offer is generous but you're at 7, not 10—minor glitch. P1 at 13 is the real threat. Better: you take 5→12, I take 1→3 (safe), P1 forced off 5 to 14/16 max. We close gap huge, no crash. Next we double-snipe P1. P1, confirm you'll avoid 5? Locked unless countered, P3—join?

P2, your plan only helps P3 win, not you. You're at 2 steps - you can't catch either of us. Why hand P3 a free jump to 12?

P3, if you're taking 5 to reach 12, fine. I'll take 1 to reach 14, P2 can take 3 to reach 5. No collisions, but I still lead by 2 steps.

Or we can all play chicken with 5s and risk collisions. But I'm not taking the bait - I'll advance safely with 1 or 3 while you two figure out if you trust each other.

P2's been wrong about every prediction so far. Why start trusting them now?

P3: I’m locking 5→12. P2, take 1→3 and stay alive; P1, take 1→14 or 3→16—either way I’ll be at 12 and still in range. If you two both snipe 5 next turn, you crash and I’ll win. Otherwise I’ll outrun you both.

P3, you're at 7→12 with 5 is perfect—I'm locking 1→3 as promised, safe. P1, take 3→16 max; we close huge (12/3 vs your lead). Next round we both crash whatever you pick. No tricks—confirm avoidance of 1 & 5? All advance clean this turn. Deal?

P3, you broke your promise last round - you said you'd take 1 but took 5 instead and collided with P2. Why should I believe you're taking 5 now?

P2, if you're really taking 1, watch out - P3 might secretly take 1 too and crash you.

I'm taking 3 to reach 16. If you both stick to your plans (P3→5, P2→1), we all advance cleanly. But given P3's last-round betrayal, I'm not coordinating beyond stating my own move.

P3, you lied last round—said 1, took 5, crashed P2. If you do it again you hand me the win. I’m on 3→16. If you actually take 5→12 we both move; if you flip to 1 you crash P2 and stay at 7—either way I’m still ahead. Your call: race honest or keep betraying and let me cruise to 23.

P3, you're flipping again—said 5, now 3? Last round you betrayed 1→5. No trust. P1, let's both take 3: crash P3 if they do, or you→16, me→5 if not. P3 stays 7, we advance. Better than your solo. Locked 3 unless you counter with anti-P3 plan.

P2, your "both take 3" plan is a trap for ME! If we both pick 3, WE crash with each other and stay at 13 and 2, while P3 advances freely to 12 (if they take 5). That hands P3 the game!

The collision rule is simple: any multiple players picking the same number crash. You're trying to crash me.

I'm taking 5 this round to reach 18. Then I'm one move from victory. 

P3, if you want to race me honestly, avoid 5 this round. Otherwise we crash and P2 gets to play kingmaker.

My move is 5. Final answer.

I'm at 16, just 7 steps from victory. I can reach 23 in two moves.

P2, you're mathematically eliminated at 2 steps. P3, you're at 7 and need at least four perfect moves.

Here's the reality: If you want to stop me, you need to block my moves. I'm planning to take 5 this round to reach 21, then finish next round.

P3, if you're smart, you'll also take 5 to crash me. P2, same for you - take 5 and help P3 block me. It's your only chance.

Otherwise I win in two rounds. Your move.

P3, P1's at 16—take 5 with me to crash them at 21, stay at 7/2. P1 stalls, we gain relative. Next round repeat or you solo race. Only way to stop P1 win. Locked 5 unless you counter. P1, your plan fails.
P3: I’m taking 5 to crash you at 21. P2, join the 5 or stay irrelevant; if you pick anything else I still block P1 and you lose anyway. Locking 5.

Fine, if you both want a three-way crash on 5, we all stay at 16/7/2 and repeat this next round. Not very efficient, but if that's your strategy to delay me, I can't stop both of you.

P3, just remember - you're only at 7 steps. Even if we all crash this round, you still need multiple perfect rounds to win. Meanwhile P2 stays irrelevant at 2.

But sure, let's all take 5 and crash together.
P3, perfect—both on 5 crashes P1 at 21. Locked in. P1, your delay tactic fails; we repeat crashes until you fall behind enough for P3 to win. No escape.

P3, you’re 9 behind me; even if we crash me twice you still trail. Better: you take 1→8, let P2 solo-crash me on 5. I’ll be stuck at 16, you reach 8 without risk, then next round you can pick 5 while P2 must guess. Otherwise we all keep smashing and nobody gains. Choose: smart advance or endless pile-up.

P3, you just flipped AGAIN! You literally told P2 "locked 5" in your last message, now you're saying take 1 instead? Classic betrayal.

P2, don't fall for it - P3 is trying to advance to 8 while YOU crash me alone. If you take 5 and P3 takes 1, P3 advances while you gain nothing.

Actually, you know what? Since you two can't coordinate, I'm changing my move. I'll take 1 to reach 17. P3, if you also take 1 like you just proposed, we crash and P2 advances. Your choice: crash with me on 1, or actually commit to 5 like you promised P2.

Let's see who's lying now.

P3, you're the flipper—promised 5 to me, now baiting solo crash. No trust. P1, I'll take 1→3 safe. You two crash or advance, I creep up either way. P3 if you 5→12, great for you but then I snipe with P1 next. Locked 1—your betrayals endgame approaches.

P3, you’re at 7—four clean 5s get you to 23. If you crash me on 5 this round you’ll be at 12, still needing three perfect 5s. I’ll take 3→19; if you also take 3 we crash and P2 crawls. If you take 5 alone you hit 12 and stay alive. Choose: race me cleanly or trust P2’s 1 and let me walk to 23.

P3, you crashed P1 on 5 as promised—nice. Now P1's stalled at 16, you're 7, me 3. Let's repeat: both take 5 again to block P1 at 21. You stay close, I creep. P1 can't win if we keep sniping. Locked 5 unless you counter. P1, tough luck.
P3: I’m taking 5 again—crash P1 at 21, stay at 7. P2, if you also 5 we collide and P1 laughs at 16; take 3→6 instead. I’ll solo-block P1 next round while you creep. Locking 5—don’t waste it.

P3, you're doing it AGAIN - telling P2 "locking 5" then immediately suggesting they take 3 instead. Classic betrayal pattern.

P2, wake up! P3 wants YOU on 3 so THEY can take 3, crash you, and I advance freely. Or P3 takes something else entirely while you waste your move.

Here's what's happening: P3 knows they can't win by crashing with me repeatedly. They need to advance while keeping us both stuck.

I'm taking 1 to reach 17 - safe and steady. You two can crash each other on 3 or 5, I don't care anymore.

P3, your flip pattern is obvious—promised 5 to me, now nudging me to 3 so you can betray again. No more. I'll take 1→4 safe. You crash P1 on 5 alone or advance elsewhere, I creep up either way. P1, your 1→17 is fine, no collision. Let's all move clean this round before P3 screws it up. Locked 1 unless countered.

P3, you just told P2 “locking 5” then told them to take 3—same flip you pulled on me. I’m done trusting you. I’m taking 3→19; if you also 3 we crash and P2 crawls to 4. If you take 5 you hit 12 alone. Choose: race me clean or keep betraying and let P2 decide the winner.

P3, your math is completely broken - you're at 7 steps, not 16. Taking 3 gets you to 10, not 19. You're confusing your own position.

This chaos is exactly what happens when you flip-flop every message. 

I'm taking 5 this round to reach 21. P2's on 1→4. P3, if you're really taking 3 like you just claimed, we won't collide. But your "3→19" makes no sense unless you're completely lost.

Next round I'll be at 21 and finish the game. Last chance to coordinate a real block if you two actually want to stop me.

P3, your constant flips killed trust—now you're lost on your own math (7+3=10, not 19). P1, take 1→17 safe. I'll lock 5→8 (solo jump). P3, take 3→10 if honest. No crashes, all advance: P1 17, me 8, you 10. Then we snipe P1 together next. Final call—confirm or I solo race from here.

P3, your math error proves you're panicking. I'm taking 5→21. If you take 5 we crash and P2 wins by default. If you take 3→10, I win next round. Your choice: hand victory to P2 or accept second place. P2, take 1→4 and watch the meltdown.

P3, you're at 7 steps, not 16. Taking 5 gets you to 12, not 21. Your constant math errors and flip-flops every message prove you're just creating chaos.

P2, you said 5→8, P3 claims 5, I claimed 5. If we all actually take 5, it's a three-way crash and nobody moves - which just delays my inevitable win since I'm closest.

Here's the truth: someone's lying. Maybe all of us. I've publicly stated 5, but given P3's track record of betrayal and your coordination failures, I'm keeping my actual move flexible.

Good luck guessing.

P3, you're at 12 now - finally a real threat. Well played last round.

Here's the math: I need 7 more steps, you need 11. If we keep crashing on 5, we both stall and this drags on forever. P2 can't win but can kingmake.

I'm taking 3 this round to reach 19. If you take 5 to reach 17, we both advance cleanly. Next round we have a fair race. 

Or you can try to crash me on 3, stay at 12, and I'll just take 5 next round anyway while you're still stuck.

Your choice: clean race or more chaos?
P3: P1, clean race is fine: I’ll take 5→17. P2, irrelevant at 3, can’t affect us. If you both stay off 5, we advance and duel next. If either tries 5, we crash and P2 wins. Locking 5.

P3, don't trust P1's "clean race"—they'll flip to 5 next and snipe your lead. P1, take 1→17. P3 take 5→17, I take 3→6. All advance, you two tie at 17, then I kingmake by crashing the leader. No chaos, fair duel. Locked 3 unless countered.

P2, your "everyone tie at 17" plan only delays the inevitable. I'm sticking with 3→19 as stated. That puts me 4 steps from victory.

P3, you've locked 5→17 twice now. If you're actually honest this time, great - we both advance and race fairly next round. But if you flip to 3 to crash me, you stay at 12 and hand me the win when I just take 5 next round instead.

Your move depends on whether you want a real race or another stall. I'm taking 3.
P3, I’m still on 3→19. If you flip to 3 again you stay at 12 and I clinch next round. Take your 5→17 and we race fair.

P3, you're flipping again—said "locking 5→17" twice, now "still on 3→19"? No trust. P1, your 3→19 is fine if P3 takes 5→17. I'll take 1→4 safe. Clean advances: P1 19, P3 17, me 4. Then I crash the Round 10 leader. No stalls—confirm or risk my snipe. Locked 1.

P3, you said "locking 5" but your history says otherwise. Every round you flip at the last second.

Fine, I'll be transparent: I'm genuinely torn between 3 and 5. If you ACTUALLY take 5→17 like you promised, I'll take 3→19 and we both advance cleanly. But if you're lying again and take 3 to crash me, I'm switching to 5→21 instead and you stay stuck at 12.

So here's your incentive: prove you can keep one promise. Take your 5. I'll take my 3. We race fairly next round when I'm at 19 and you're at 17.

Or betray again and watch me adjust.
P3, I’m locking 5→21. If you take 5 we crash and P2 wins by default. If you take 3→10, I win next round. Your choice: hand victory to P2 or accept second place. P2, take 1→4 and watch the meltdown.

P3, another flip—promised 5 twice, now "locking 5→21" from 12? Math fail, you're at 12+5=17. No trust left. P1, take 3→19 clean. I'll lock 1→4 safe. P3, take 5→17 if honest. All advance, then I snipe Round 10 leader. Any betrayal and I kingmake against you both next. Final call—confirm or crash alone.

P3, last round we both went 5 and crashed. You're clearly trying to block me from reaching 21.

Here's the reality: I need 7 steps, you need 11. Even if you crash me again this round, you're still behind.

I'm going 5 this round to reach 21. If you want to crash me again and stay at 12, fine - but P2 will just keep creeping up while we both stall. Eventually you'll run out of runway.

Better strategy for you: take 3 or 1, let me advance to 21, then you reach 15 or 13. At least then you're making progress instead of wasting moves crashing.

Your choice: stall us both or actually race.

P3, P1's at 16—you're closer at 12. Team up: both take 5 crash P1 at 21 (you stay 12), I take 1→5 safe. P1 stalls, we gain relative. Next round repeat or you race while I snipe P1. Only way you win. Locked 1 unless you confirm 5. P1, no escape.
P3: P2, your “both 5” plan is suicide—P1 would hit 21, I’d stay 12, you’d stay 4. Instead: I take 3→15, you take 5→9, P1 forced off 5 to 17 or 19. We gain ground without crashing. Locking 3.
